text:
Phylum Arthropoda is the largest phylum in the animal kingdom, which includes such familiar forms as lobsters, crabs, spiders, mites, insects, centipedes, and millipedes. About 84 percent of all known species of animals are members of this phylum. Arthropods are represented in every habitat on Earth and show a great variety of adaptations.

Insects are invertebrates with bodies divided into three parts; they usually have three pairs of legs, two pairs of wings and antennae. Examples; ants, bees, and wasps (order Hymenoptera) beetles and weevils (order Coleoptera) butterflies and moths (order Lepidoptera) caddisflies (order Trichoptera) cockroaches (order Blattodea) crickets, grasshoppers, and katydids (order Orthoptera) diplurans (order Diplura) dragonflies and damselflies (order Odonata). 

Metamorphosis

Insects that have an incomplete metamorphosis life cycle include true bugs, grasshoppers, cockroaches, termites, praying mantises, crickets, and lice.

Insects with complete metamorphosis include beetles, bees, ants, butterflies, moths, fleas, and mosquitoes.

Flour beetles are members of the darkling beetle genera Tribolium or Tenebrio. They are pests of cereal silos and are widely used as laboratory animals, as they are easy to keep.

Ticks are arachnids, which means they're more closely related to spiders than they are to flies or mosquitos.

Ticks are typically 3 to 5 mm long, part of the superorder Parasitiformes.

Spiders are also arachnids, but ticks aren't spiders. Spiders' bodies have two segments, the cephalothorax and the abdomen, while ticks' bodies aren't segmented in any way. A tick's body is small and relatively flat, so it's easy for it to attach itself to a host and eat its fill before the host notices.

There are different types of mosquitos. The most popular ones are Culex and Anopheles. 

Eggs of Culex are vertically laid in clusters on the surface of the water whereas of anopheles are laid singly and horizontally on the surface of the water. Larva of Culex mosquito is bottom feeder whereas of anopheles mosquito is surface feeder.

Termites are highly specialized social insects. They form colonies and have three distinct forms (castes) which perform different roles. The parent caste which consist of the king and the queen and they function for reproduction. The soldier caste which protects colonies, and the workers which lack pigmentation in most species and functions in food gathering and building. The workers are also sterile and wingless

Male cockroach differs from female cockroach by having a larger size, narrower abdomen and the presence of anal styles. The female cockroach lacks styles.

 

UNN PUTME Example

1. Spider belongs to the same class with_____

A. mosquito B. tick C. chiddae D. cockroach

(B. Spiders are also arachnids, but ticks aren't spiders. Spiders' bodies have two segments, the cephalothorax and the abdomen, while ticks' bodies aren't segmented in any way, 2014/2015, no 8) 

 

2. Centipedes are

A. equally dangerous as millipedes B. less dangerous than millipedes C. more dangerous than all D. not dangerous at all

(Centipedes are more dangerous. A centipede has poisonous claws found on its segment which it uses to kill prey but a millipede is a harmless decomposer thus more friendly, 2006/2007, no 3)

 

3. The caste of termites that lacks pigmentation is the 

A. king B. Worker C. Solder D. Queen

(B. The soldier caste which protects colonies, and the workers which lack pigmentation in most species and functions in food gathering and building. The workers are also sterile and wingless, 2018/2019, no 17)

 

4. Increasing complexity due to multicellularity first appeared in this animal group

A. protozoa B. coelenterate C. Sarcodina D. Protista

(B. The vastly more complex higher animals have evolved from humble ancestors resembling coelenterates, and these higher animals owe their complexity to more sophisticated. Coelenterates can be called as the simplest animal group that has true tissues and have the characteristic coelenteron or the gastrovascular cavity, 2007/2008, no 1)

 

5. One of these arthropods is a carrier of viruses and other micro organism

A. termite B. ant C. bee D. flea

(D. Fleas are vectors for viral, bacterial and rickettsial diseases of humans and other animals, as well as of protozoan and helminth parasites. Bacterial diseases carried by fleas include murine or endemic typhus and bubonic plague, 2008/2009, no 10)

 

6. Incomplete metamorphosis is found in these organisms except

A. Dragon fly B. House fly C. Locust D. Cockroach

(B. Insects that have an incomplete metamorphosis life cycle include true bugs, grasshoppers, cockroaches, termites, praying mantises, crickets, and lice, 2011/2012, no 2)

 

7. Which one of these insects is to be found in flour mills?

A. Trogoderma B. Tribolium C. Sitophilus D. Callosobruchus

(B. Flour beetles are members of the darkling beetle genera Tribolium or Tenebrio. They are pests of cereal silos and are widely used as laboratory animals, as they are easy to keep, 2010/2011, no 3)

 

8. Which one is not an insect?

A. Tick B. Ant C. Beetle D. Locust

(A. Ticks are actually arachnids, which means they're more closely related to spiders than they are to flies or mosquitos, 2011/2012, no 12)

 

9. The most successful group of animals in terms of diversity of species is

A. Mollusca B. Arthropoda C. Mammalia D. Cnidaria

(B. Phylum Arthropoda, 2012/2013, no 6)

 

10. The male cockroach differs from the female by having 

A. mandibles B. a pair of styles C. spiracles D. a pair of cerci

(B. Male cockroach differs from female cockroach by having a larger size, narrower abdomen and the presence of anal styles. The female cockroach lacks styles 2019/2020, no 12)

 

JAMB Examples

1. The main distinguishing features between the soldier termite and other members of the caste are the

A. presence of wings, possession of a small head and large thorax B. presence of wings, possession of a large thorax and a small head C. absence of wings, possession of strong mandibles and a large head D. absence of wings, possession of big head and the absence of mandible

(C. absence of wings, possession of strong mandibles and a large head)

 

2. The adaptive importance of nuptial flight from termite colonies is to

A. disperse the reproductives in order to establish new colonies B. provide abundant food for birds and other animals during the early rains C. ensure cross-breeding between members of one colony and another D. expel the reproductives so as to provide enough food for other members

(A. disperse the reproductives in order to establish new colonies)

 

3. Which of the following distinguishes a butterfly from a moth?

A. the wings of butterfly rest horizontally but those of moth rest vertically B. Both are active during the day C. they have similar antennae D. the abdomen of moth is fatter than that of butterfly

(A. the wings of butterfly rest horizontally but those of moth rest vertically)
